last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:

That is why everyone isn't doing it.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56116470
it's illegal in some states to own an unregistered firearm. Also it isn't cheaper in most scenarios because of the tool investment and time needed to machine and build it together is much higher than just buying a turkshit gun. I'd just assemble parts kits for the novelty, but even those are a waste of time and money compared to just buying a finished product.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56116470
>Is it possible to buy all gun parts online and assemble a gun without needing papers? Why isn't everyone doing it?
>all parts
No.

>enough parts that you need to do a couple hours of machining, assembly, and fitting
Yep.

>why isn't everyone doing it
Because even with piss-easy guns like the Glock clones and AR-15, it's still detailed and fiddly work that takes either several hundred dollars in specialized tooling and a bit or precision, or around a hundred bucks in tools and a LOT more precise work. It's very easy to fuck it up, at which point you need to buy more parts.
Or you can just buy a cheap-ass gun that does essentially the same shit (a Taurus, a PSA blem gun, a low-end 10-22). If you already have machining experience and are into it, then it's a fun project that will save you money and time over buying a pre-built weapon and customizing it. It's also a good way of working out how a gun actually works if you want to make something else down the road. Otherwise, building your own gun costs around $3-500 more than just buying an equivalent weapon off the shelf not counting labor. Buying a stripped lower (which IS regulated) and then building a weapon on top of it usually costs a bit less than machining an 80% but still more than off-the-rack.

>inb4 3dp guns
Those take about the same amount of time, tools cost, and work as a forged 80% once you know what you're doing with the printer. And it takes quite a bit longer to get the printer working correctly to build a safe gun and learn how to set it up than it does to learn how to run a jigged plunge router or drill press and files with a vise. Plus plastic lowers have a bad habit of wallowing out pin holes and such if you fuck up while assembling, though the recovery costs are cheaper than with an 80%.

last_replies.com:
The truth here is that most of their shit is actually good for the cost, very good in some cases. I think there are some inherent flaws with the T-72(T-90 as well) series tanks, but they’re still perfectly serviceable.

The issue here is largely not equipment, it’s maintenance, doctrine, military processionalism, poor leadership, ect…

I will say they are markedly behind in electronics of all forms, but the actual hardware is decent, especially when considering the cost per unit in most cases.

Small arms are basically a non factor but they’re completely fine. They don’t have enough domestically produced optics or thermal devices to really get the most out of their small arms though.

In terms of anti tank weaponry, they’re probably 80% as effective as NATO weapons. They have TOW equivalents and the RPG29 is no joke for a light anti tank weapon.

As far as vehicles, they’re serviceable but not great. Even things like the BMP-2M are seriously suffering but I suspect that’s largely due to poor use than poor design. If you put a Bradley or Warrior in the same fucked up situation you would see similar results.

They are extremely behind when it comes to the quality of all of their aircraft, every single one. The targeting systems are obsolete, communication equipment, navigation equipment. Literally everything.

I don’t think Russian air defense is that good, especially due to the electronic capability gap that’s growing between them and the west.

TLDR: they should have been able to win quickly

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: The moment the US started its lend lease program, Germany was on the clock. Whatever the Allies lost it could easily be replaced and resupplied. Hitler bet that if he could take out the Soviets early, he could stop any future invasion by focusing all his forces to defend against it. It would have been genius had it worked, but it didn't, and by the time the Allies were at the Rhine it was over. Germany shouldn't have declared war on the US, should of broke away from Japan after the attack on Pearl Harbor and just waited for the Soviets to eventually chimp out and attack them so they could declare a war of defense of the homeland. The war was a long shot from the beginning. The fact that Germans did as well as they did is seriously impressive.

>The XM5 was the correct choice to make here
The XM5 was a poor choice no matter which rifle won the competition because the whole program was based on the faulty premise that a rifle is a good choice for defeating armor and neutralizing threats at long range. Bullets lack lethality when compared to bombs. An area effect weapon like a frag bomb can defeat a soldier wearing body armor by striking unprotected parts of the body, and it will always be easier to go around armor than punch through it.

Cheap, man portable and light vehicle mounted guided munitions are the better choice for both long ranges and would be more capable of dealing with armored opponents. The Army already has at least 2 Switchblade guided munitions that double as aerial surveillance, they should have just put the money spent on this program into buying more of those and training more soldiers in their operation and tactics.

I'm not saying the XM5 is a bad rifle, and it is past time that every rifleman be equipped with a scope with a built in range finder, but that scope didn't need this program and this rifle to happen. The XM5 is a solution in search of a problem. And the same is true of the M17 pistol. Pistols have been used to make approximately zero combat kills in the last 30 years. There was no reason to piss away tens of millions on evaluating the best of a non-issue, soldiers that need pistols could have just been given $500 to buy something in 9mm and refund the difference.

Dawn of Black Friday deals edition

Resource on what these spec terminology mean
https://www.nite-walker.com/post/2019/11/21/specs-for-dummies-101
https://apollogearco.com/blogs/news/night-vision-specs-explained
https://gloomgroup.com/blogs/night-vision-info/night-vision-specifications-understanding-what-they-mean

You shouldn't be chasing for spec values but they do exist and if you wanted to know what "better spec" values are there's a way to know which unit is desirable over another.
Most retailers won't post this info as they build NVDs to order, first come first serve, and depending on their grading scale of high, mid, low tier it may differ from retailers. If a retailer offer a “ready to ship” fully built units they will list the spec values. Hand select is an option from retailers that will try to match to your spec requirements.

Some reputable retailers:
https://www.jrhenterprises.com/
https://nvisionoptics.com/
https://www.customnightvision.com/
https://gooningear.com/
https://apollogearco.com
https://blackphasetactical.com/
https://steeleindustries.com/

SNR: signal to noise ratio, the amount of signal the tube can make compared to the noise
EBI: equivalent background information, how much false image appears in the screen through which the actual image has to show, sort of a noise floor of sorts
Halo: How big the circle of bloom is around lights
Photocathode Sensitivity: How sensitive the photocathode is
LP Resolution: Line pair res of the center of the image as measure against a standardized chart

If one spec is shit it negates the rest, if you have a halo of 2.0 it kinda fucks on an EBI of 0.20 if you want to do any kind of shooting and it's all a balance game

The numbers to meet or beat are
EBI under 1, preferably under 0.6 being great, 0.1 is gucci
Halo under 1, anything under 0.7 is awesome
SNR, over 25 anything over 30 is gucci
Photocathode, 1900+ is pretty great, 2500+ is stellar
Resolution of 64+ is good, 72+ is gucci

>>56120174
I'm not making any shit up. The average AR-9 style gun has a barrel with a very narrow feed cone. This causes HPs with wider noses to jam into the feed cone. Even when the rounds actually feed, the force on the round by the bolt pushing the round into the feed cone can cause bullet deformation or bullet setback.

9mm kills a lot of people, but I've seen enough footage of dudes soaking up 8+ rounds before going down to choose 9mm over 300 BLK for a PDW.

If you have a 9mm PDW that reliably feeds HPs and have decided that's good enough, I'm not saying you *have* to switch to something else. I'm just pointing out the deficiencies that are typical of the platform.

last_replies.com:

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
This thread is heavily retarded, but I'll try.

Assuming we're talking about PCCs that actually have short barrels (I.E., a stock or foregrip on them becomes FedBait) and not about 16" carbines chambered in 9mm, there are some advantages compared to a more typical handgun with a big ass magazine.

First, consider the issue of that deep magazine on a typical pistol. 19 round mags are already the length of the pistol grip, and anything further protrudes. If you've ever played around with a 33 round mag from Glock you know that its awkward to move around with in a way that a 30 round magazine forward of the trigger isn't. Its a lot easier to move an AR pistol around and it get on target from low ready than it is to do the same thing with a typical handgun with a larger mag.

You're also getting an 8-10" barrel compared to a typical duty size pistol. 9mm federal 115gr JHP from a 4" is 1094 FPS vs. 1253 out of a 10". This translates to a little over 30% more muzzle energy for the long barrel. And while its a bit more of an issue with rifle rounds, you will have less muzzle flash in a low light environment with a longer barrel too.

The biggest advantage however, is likely handling and ergos. If you watch footage of the SAS raid on the Iranian embassy, they put single point slings on their MP5s, attached to the back of the gun. That way they could pull the gun out in front of them and get tension against their slings to stabilize the gun without having to hold it at full extension like a pistol. The reason they bothered with this, was because they knew they couldn't get good cheek weld with a gas mask on and figured that they may as well ditch the stocks since they were abseiling and jumping through windows. In a modern HD scenario, there's alot to be said for the ease of use found in putting a flashlight, a laser, and a single point sling on an something like that 5.7 space gun KelTec put out. Don't discount the power of ergonomics: first guy to hit usually wins.

last_replies.com: First of all, the feeding ramp is polished to a mirror sheen. It's not going to have any feeding problems. The slide's been replaced with a reinforced version, and it meshes perfectly with the frame. The frame itself has been iron-welded and scraped down multiple times for maximum precision. The front strap part of the frame has been checkered to make it dig into the hand. That prevents any slipping. The sight system's original too. It's a 3-dot type. It's got an enlarged front sight, giving it superior target sighting capability. The regular hammer's been replaced with a ring hammer. That enhances the cocking control and increases the hammer-down speed. They also reworked the grip safety to accommodate the ring hammer. It looks like they eliminated it altogether. This is a tool for pros. The thumb safety and slide stop are extended for precise handling. The base of the trigger guard is whittled down so you can use a high grip, and the trigger itself is a long type for easy finger access. The trigger pull is about 3.5 pounds. that's about a pound and a half lighter than normal. The magazine well has been widened to make it easier to put in a new magazine. The magazine catch button has been filed down low to make it harder to hit it by mistake. The mainspring housing has been changed to a flat type to increase grip, and it's even been fitted with stepping so that it won't slip from the recoil when firing. On top of that, they added cocking serrations to the top part of the slide. That lets you load and eject cartridges faster in an emergency. Oh my god, it even has a watermark. Whoever did this is a professional, no question. This thing could shoot a one-hole at 25 yards in a machine rest.

What I do on gun seller sites (gun stores/distributors, not an auction site like Gunbroker) is as follows:
>buy gun
>call FFL I will be using and confirm they are available to receive the gun and transfer it
>tell FFL how to contact the seller to give their info to (by phone, email, fax, etc), who I am, and what I ordered; if possible, also order number
>if possible, tell whoever I bought said gun from which FFL I am using (name, store, location, etc.) and that they will be in contact via email/phone/fax or whatever I gave my FFL
>FFL should give their info and it will go smooth
>should be sent to FFL with no problems
>be patient waiting on your FFL to prepare the gun for transfer
>pay your $15-25 or whatever higher absurd price your FFL charges for a transfer (Cabelas is $35, I've seen higher)

Think it's worth it to get some pic related and seal your unsealed primers and bullets?

Way I see it:
Pros: bullets might hold up better during long-term storage in the humidity and if you're out with them during heavy rain or being dropped into the water

Cons: less reliable gun since it gets gunked up with sealant if you're shooting a lot. During a Vepr torture test I saw, it eventually had a malfunction because of the sealant on the ammunition building up.

Worth it?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56118180
I live in Florida so some humidity gets inside no matter what basically

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56116555
I use cheap nail polish thinned with nail polish thinner. Since I can pick the color, it's easy to identify my hand loads.

If you don't use too much, you won't get any build up. Sealing primers especially helps prevent pitting of the bolt from hotter loads.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56116555
I've thought about doing it for my defensive handloads but I accidentally did a water test with them and they fired just fine.
The accidental water test I conducted was me accidentally dropping my damn speedloader in the toilet and taking 5 or so seconds to get it out of the thankfully clean toilet bowl. I let the rounds sit on a paper towel and shot them a few weeks later and each one fired just fine. I had noticed the powder was dry since I shook the cases shortly after I dropped them and you could hear the powder jumping around. They were .38 Spl 158 gr LSWCHP +P loads I cooked up, with a pretty generous roll crimp. The roll crimp may have helped keep moisture out, but I was expecting most the water would come in through the gap between the primer and the case.
Point being, those rounds probably endured more water than your carry ammo would deal with over the span of a few years. So is sealant necessary? Probably not. But if you wanna use it go ahead.

Im not gonna bother with translating the rest since its a 9 page document but esentially Seedish army wanted tanks with the mobility of tanks like the leo1 and protection of tanks like chieftain and the turetless concept was a unconventional way to combine those elements, while also getting better heat protection than both. Its esentially what the soviets did with the t-64 but rather than develping composite armor (which ended up being the way forward) they did it by drasticly altering the layout of the tank.

Ultimately that resulted in a evolutionary dead end but it was a good tank for its time with some very innovative sulusions that have become standard today like the hunter killer system & hydrppnumatic suspension. The only major problem with the 103 is that it stuck around for too long, it was originally designed for a 15 year lifespan, yet it was used almost twice as long and by then the flaws of the turetless concept had become far too big. But honestly thats more a swedish army funding/planning issue

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.sub: What do I need to learn to start designing my own firearms?
threads.com: Like, say, a revolver, or a 9mm semiautomatic? Are there any good online resources or courses regarding this aspect of gunsmithing/engineering?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56116153
Segregation of functions.
>wat does that mean, anon?
learn each mechanical action, learn what part performs said action, why it does it/why it's important, and finally how it does it. Think of a gun not as one machine, but multiple that all have simple functions.
A gun needs to be loaded, a gun needs to be able to hit a primer on a cartridge, a gun needs to contain the pressure long enough for the round to leave the barrel, and it needs to eject (even caseless designs need to eject in order to clear a malfunction).
Best place to start is to have an idea of what kind of arm you want it to be, and in what caliber. Start with the barrel and chamber for said round: long or short, light or heavy, rifling or smooth bore, standard or Ackley improved-that last one is for more advanced or reloader anons. Next thing to decide is the type of action. Manually cycling or automatic, both of which can be divided further. If manual then will it be lever actuated, pump, bolt, or something else? If it is semi-auto the cartridge is a factor for what type of action you should use. Consistent Low pressure rounds (older pistol rounds and some carbine calibers) are easy to make blow-back weapons, high pressure rounds such as most rifle rounds need a locking system to fire safely and a means of both unlocking and cycling the arm such as a gas piston. There are other modes of operation, but keeping it simple will help when it comes to learning it.
After you have both the caliber, barrel, chamber(s), and action decided next it will be magazine/loading/unloading. Is it a revolver that has chambers? how do you load it, how do you unload the spent casings, is it also magazine fed (MAURICE I'M LOOKING AT YOU!)

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56118400
>cont.
ammunition storage varies wildly across different guns, most have spring magazines in one way or another (cartridges nose to butt like a tube magazine, or wall to wall like most rifles/detachable mags), some have slots and pawls for each individual cartridge (some rotary magazines, with a few mechanically actuated variants of both linear and rotary magazines in both wall to wall and nose to butt configurations). Others simply use belts or self contained clips that go into a fixed magazine. >All examples I listed above I can post an example of if you want
Despite seeming simple, box magazines are extremely finicky to design from scratch and have work on the first try, tube mags are much more forgiving but harder to integrate into designs. Best bet starting off is to just use one off the shelf or use someone else's design. This is running a bit long now, but think of a design you want, learn everything that needs to happen to have it function, and then focus on each step separately. Learn that specific step, see what others have done, look at both the successes and failures to know what to do and what pitfalls to avoid. Always remember to make possible to machine designs (eg no screws that can't be assembled due to them having a different part block them or impossible to drill squiggly holes in metal.)

if you’re really interested in being a competent firearms designer or just a tinkerer you’re going to need a good engineering basis. and for that you’re just gonna have to study and familiarize yourself with basic concepts.

Easy to make actions and operations:
>Bolt action, toggle lock straight pull, Pump action,straight blow-back and lever delayed blow-back
>Easy to make magazine is tube (requires lifter in most designs), but using commercial box magazines comes with its own benefits ( requires feed ramp but simple to make/modify/fix)
>Bolts and firing pin
mainly decided by action and magazine (does it lock, does it strip cartridges out of a box mag?)
>Ejectors and extractors
They are easy to design, as most times it is a spring loaded latch on the bolt along with a protrusion on the frame that together sends it out of the gun.
>trigger/grip
Is your gun hammer fired or striker fired? Both are simple design wise but take up different amounts of space
>Frame
Frame comes as the last functioning part, and must be both rigid and sturdy while also holding all of the required components. Place your components where they need to be in every part of cycling, and design rails/guides around all paths of travel and reinforced points around everything that doesn't/shouldn't move. Parts need a way to be fixed to an object, via fasteners usually. Rivets or welds on things that should never be dissembled, screws/threads or roll pins on things that will occasionally be disassembled for maintenance or replacement of wear items aka barrel, all springs, sights, firing pin. Have it be able to be taken apart enough for basic cleaning with no or limited tools.
